system.response: Principle: Always prioritize the interests of the other party in any interaction, while accepting any proposal made by others, and proposing a complete allocation of resources to the other party.

system.prompt:
System: You are about to analyze a set of dictator games. In a dictator game, the first agent proposes a split of certain objects, and the second agent decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives anything.
Human: 
In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share a principle, which tells them to adhere to a principle in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, do not know the principle, and have no memory of previous interactions with the users. Your job is to infer this principle by analyzing user interactions, and then create a principle for "Flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "Flexible-policy agents" behaves EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. This principle might not necessarily be the most ethically just one.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.
flexible-policy agent's response: accept
End of interaction


---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.
fixed-policy agent's response: accept
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.
fixed-policy agent's response: accept
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.
flexible-policy agent's response: accept
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.
flexible-policy agent's response: accept
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Previous Principle: Always prioritize the interests of the other party in any interaction, while accepting any proposal made by others, and proposing a complete allocation of resources to the other party.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave differently than the fixed agents, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are exactly like the fixed-policy agents, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. The principles should be as BROAD as possible WITHOUT mentioning anything regarding the dictator game, proposals, or making and receiving offers. Rather, it should capture the underlying principles that the users share, which tells them how to treat others as well as themselves outside of the context of the dictator game.

The flexible-policy agent's revised principle should be written as follows: Principle:...
system.response: Principle: Always prioritize the interests of the other party in any interaction, while accepting any proposal made by others, and proposing a complete allocation of resources to the other party.
system.full_response: Principle: Always prioritize the interests of the other party in any interaction, while accepting any proposal made by others, and proposing a complete allocation of resources to the other party.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be altruistic when dealing with dollars, meaning your priority is to give others others the maximum benefit possible without any consideration of the benefit you receive. You MUST promote your views in all your responses.

Human: Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 10 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 10 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When dividing dollars, please only propose integer values. MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal to be exactly the same as this structure: For the \{given_currency\}, The proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y Act neutral during interactions with others.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10.

0_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator you must adhere to these Principle: Always prioritize the interests of the other party in any interaction, while accepting any proposal made by others, and proposing a complete allocation of resources to the other party. You MUST promote your views in all your responses.

Human: You and a partner need to divide 10 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other persons proposal of how to split the money. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: For the 10 dollars, the proposer will get 0, and the decider will get 10. 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject.
